title: 114_s2962
content: The Act titled "Affordable Housing Credit Improvement Act of 2016" increases state allocations. The Act "Affordable Housing Credit Improvement Act of 2016" amends the Internal Revenue Code to phase in increases in the per capita dollar amount and minimum ceiling amount for the calendar year 2016. The Affordable Housing Credit Improvement Act of 2016 increases the per capita dollar amount and minimum ceiling amount annually, starting at $2.35 and $2,690,000 for 2016, and reaching $3.53 and $3,228,000 thereafter. The Affordable Housing Credit Improvement Act of 2016 raises the per capita dollar amount annually, starting at $2.35 and $2,690,000 for 2016, and increasing to $3.53 and $3,228,000 thereafter. Amendments include adjustments for calendar years 2019, 2020, and beyond. The per capita dollar amount is increased to $3.53 and the minimum ceiling amount to $4,035,000 for calendar years after December 31, 2016. The amendment to section 42(h) of the Code adjusts the cost-of-living amounts for calendar years after December 31, 2016. The per capita dollar amount is increased to $3.53 and the minimum ceiling amount to $4,035,000. The amendment to section 42(h) of the Code adjusts cost-of-living amounts for calendar years beginning after December 31, 2021. SEC. 3. AVERAGE INCOME TEST. The amendment to section 42(g) of the Internal Revenue Code introduces a new subparagraph (C) which establishes an average income test for residential projects. This test requires that 40 percent or more of the units be rent-restricted and occupied by individuals with income below a specified limit. The taxpayer must designate the imputed income limitation for each unit, with an average not exceeding 60 percent of area median gross income. The designated imputed income limitation for any unit should be in 10-percent increments. The imputed income limitation for each unit should not exceed 80 percent of area median gross income, as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments have been made to clarify the rules regarding income limitations for housing units. The amendments made by this section clarify the rules for income limitations on housing units, with a special rule for average income tests. These changes apply to elections made under section 42(g)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 sets a minimum credit rate of 4 percent for new or existing buildings placed in service after December 31, 2015. The amendments apply to buildings placed in service after that date.
